{{sources|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Tosun Bayrak | birth_name = Tosun Bekir Bayraktaroğlu<ref>[http://www.sufi.com.tr/kitaplar/ani-biyografi/amerikada-bir-turk.aspx Amerika'da Bir Türk]</ref> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1926|01|21}}<ref>Amerika'da Bir Türk [http://www.sufi.com.tr/kitaplar/ani-biyografi/amerikada-bir-turk.aspx], p.19</ref> | birth_place = [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|02|15|1926|01|21}} | residence = [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | occupation = Sufi sheikh, writer, translator, artist | spouse = Jean Linder Bayrak | website = {{URL|tosunbayrak.com}} | footnotes = }} {{Sufism}} '''Sheikh Tosun Bayrak al-Jerrahi al-Halveti''' (January 21, 1926 – 15 February 2018) was an author, translator and [[Sufi]]. He served as a government official in [[Ankara]], Honorary Consul of [[Turkey]] in [[Morocco]] and was the Sheikh of the [[Jerrahi]] Order in America.<ref>[http://www.fonsvitae.com/tosunbayrakibnarabi.html The Tree of Being] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516072115/http://www.fonsvitae.com/tosunbayrakibnarabi.html |date=2008-05-16 }}</ref> He died on February 15, 2018.<ref>[https://www.alaturka.us/obituary-sufi-leader-tosun-bayraktaroglu/ Obituary: Sufi leader Tosun Bayraktaroglu]</ref>
==Biography== ===Early life=== Bayrak was born in [[Istanbul]] in 1926.<ref name=obit>Ahmet Sait Akcay, [https://www.aa.com.tr/en/culture-and-art/obituary-sufi-leader-tosun-bayraktaroglu/1069998 Obituary: Sufi leader Tosun Bayraktaroglu]. Andalou Agency, 21 February 2018. Accessed 28 October 2018.</ref> During his childhood, he'd been raised without religion in the household, having rarely visited a mosque with his parents; his interest in Hindu and Buddhist philosopher during high school was one of his few experiences with religion.<ref name=moth>Matt Hanson, [https://www.dailysabah.com/arts-culture/2018/09/01/the-moth-and-the-flame-in-memory-of-tosun-bayrak The moth and the flame: In memory of Tosun Bayrak]. [[Daily Sabah]], 31 August 2018. Accessed 28 October 2018.</ref> Early in life, his grandfather helped to spark his interest in art and poetry with trips to museums as well as [[Topkapı Palace]].<ref name=moth/> Initially, he studied [[Biological Sciences]] at [[Robert College]], graduating in 1945.<ref name=obit/> It was during his time in college that he first became exposed to Islam as a living practice, lodging on weekends with his aunt who prayed five times a day and fasted during [[Ramadan]].<ref name=moth/>
Bayrak later went on to study [[Art]], [[Architecture]], and [[Art History]] in the Studios of [[Fernand Léger]] and [[Andre Lhote]] in [[Paris]];<ref name=moth/> [[Architecture]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]];<ref name=obit/> and [[History of Art]] at the [[Courtauld Institute of Art]], [[London]]. While in London, he was an associate of poet [[Can Yücel]] and former [[Prime Minister of Turkey]] [[Bülent Ecevit]].<ref name=moth/> He received a Masters in Fine Arts from [[Rutgers University]].<ref name=obit/>
===Sufism=== In 1970 Bayrak met [[Muzaffer Ozak]], who became his spiritual teacher, at the Jerrahi Lodge in Instanbul.<ref name=obit/><ref>William Rory Dickson, [https://books.google.com.sa/books?id=HCiLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA3&dq=jerrahi+america&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjj0IvShLDeAhUMC8AKHfz9BuQQ6AEILzAB#v=onepage&q=jerrahi%20america&f=false Living Sufism in North America: Between Tradition and Transformation], p. 108. [[Albany, New York|Albany]]: [[SUNY Press]], 2015. {{ISBN|9781438457581}}</ref> Bayrak became a Sheikh of the Halveti-Jerrahi order and resided near the Jerrahi Order of America mosque in [[Spring Valley, New York]] a few years later.<ref>[http://www.sufism.org/books/names.html#tosun The Most Beautiful Names]</ref> He acted as the spiritual guide of the Jerrahi Order of the Americas starting from 1977,<ref>[http://www.forusa.org/fellowship/sep_oct_01/1001_13.html The Meaning of Age] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20040626145532/http://www.forusa.org/fellowship/sep_oct_01/1001_13.html |date=2004-06-26 }}</ref>, and he founded the official mosque of the Order's American branch in [[Chestnut Ridge, New York]] in 1990.<ref name=moth/> Though at one time an admirer of [[Fethullah Gülen]], Bayrak condemned the [[Gülen movement]] at a winter 2016 art exhibit in Istanbul due to the movement's alleged involvement in the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt]].<ref name=moth/>
{{cquote|“Service should be from the moment you are born until the moment you give your last breath, but you have to find out in what way. That's what's most important. We have to find out in what manner we are supposed to serve.” <ref>"The World is Beautiful" An interview with Sheikh Tosun Bayrak al-Jerrahi [http://www.wie.org/j18/bayrak.asp?page=2]</ref>}}
In response to the [[January 2015 Île-de-France attacks]], which ended as Bayrak was planning a Friday sermon, he declared that the perpetrators were insane, not Muslims, and opposed the key teachings of Islam.<ref>Jane Lerner and Richard Liebson, [https://www.lohud.com/story/news/local/2015/01/09/local-muslims-jews-horrified-terror-france/21530145/ Local Muslims, Jews horrified by terror in Paris]. [[The Journal News]], 9 January 2015. Accessed 1 November 2018.</ref> Bayrak passed away in New York on 15 February 2018 at the age of 92.<ref name=obit/>
==Works== ===Artisty=== Bayrak taught art and art history at [[Fairleigh Dickinson University]], where he helped to establish the Fine Arts Division.<ref name=moth/> His work was exhibited widely in the United States,<ref>[http://www.fonsvitae.com/tosunbayrakibnarabi.html The Tree of Being] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516072115/http://www.fonsvitae.com/tosunbayrakibnarabi.html |date=2008-05-16 }}</ref> and he became a [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim]] fellow in 1965.<ref name=moth/><ref>[http://www.worldwisdom.com/Public/Authors/Detail.asp?AuthorID=97&WhatType=1 Tosun Bayrak]</ref> He retired from the art world in the 1970s and devoted his life to the study and teaching of [[Islam]] and Sufism.
{{cquote|“Both my wife and I were artists, and we felt very strongly that it was feeding our egos. Art, art exhibitions, and the consequences of being accepted and successful are incredible food for your ego, which is the Sufi's enemy. The final straw was when we went to Rome to visit a friend, a sculptor, and there was a very pretty young girl there whom my friend introduced me to. And she was so adoring to me. She said, "Ohhh, I know you. I love your art." She was completely praising me, and I saw the ego suddenly rise up and say, "Aha! This beautiful, spiritual girl is telling you that you are a great artist." So I said, "Oh, my God! That's it. It's over." I hit the ego on the head and decided I was finished with it all.<ref>"The World is Beautiful" An interview with Sheikh Tosun Bayrak al-Jerrahi [http://www.wie.org/j18/bayrak.asp?page=2]</ref>}}
===Translation=== Bayrak translated dozens of books on Islamic spirituality, but he was particularly known for his efforts on the works of the Sufi mystic [[Ibn Arabi]]. One of his best known works is ''Ibn Arabi: The Tree of Being''. His translations of classic works of Sufism include [[Abdul Qadir Gilani]]'s ''Secret of Secrets'', ''Inspirations'', and ''The Book of Sufi Chivalry'', ''[[Suhrawardiyya|Suhrawardi]]: The Shape of Light'', ''The Name and the Named: Divine Attributes of God'', and [[Imam Birgivi]]'s ''The Path of Muhammad''.<ref name=obit/>
==See also== *[[Ibn Arabi]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = Uppspretta | painting_alignment = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | image = Uppspretta by Evening.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | artist = [[Toyism|Toyists]] | year = 2013 | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | material = | subject = Islandic mythology | height_metric = 900 | width_metric = 3600 | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | city = [[Keflavík]] | coordinates = {{coord|63.999547|-22.569056|type:landmark|display=title}} | owner = | website = {{URL|uppspretta.com}} }} '''Uppspretta''' is the name of a [[Toyism|Toyist]] artwork situated in the [[Iceland]]ic town of [[Keflavík]]. In 2013, a neglected [[water tower]] being nine meters in height and thirty-six meters in circumference, was transformed into an object of art.<ref>Nordwest-Zeitung, [http://www.nwzonline.de/friesland/kultur/maskenspiel-und-bunte-farben_a_17,0,2199234095.html Maskenspiel und bunte Farben], 28 August 2014 {{ger}}</ref> The painting shows the story of a [[puffin]] named Uppspretta.<ref>Krant van Coevorden, [http://www.krantvancoevorden.nl/nieuws/26695/oude-watertank-in-ijsland-krijgt-facelift-van-de-toyisten/ Oude watertank in IJsland krijgt facelift van de Toyisten], 28 May 2013 {{nl}}</ref>
This largest artistic wall painting of Iceland<ref>Víkurfréttir, [http://www.vf.is/mannlif/staersta-veggmalverk-a-islandi-gert-i-keflavik/58129 Stærsta veggmálverk á Íslandi gert í Keflavík], 7 July 2013 {{is icon}}</ref> was officially opened by mayor Árni Sigfússon of [[Reykjanesbær]] on 6 September 2013.<ref name="Beek 5-14" /> It is situated in a popular recreation area of Keflavík.<ref>Reykjanesbær, [http://www.reykjanesbaer.is/upplysingatorg/frettir-og-tilkynningar/uppspretta-vatnstankur-verdur-listaverk-/19420/ Uppspretta, vatnstankur verður listaverk], 28 April 2014 {{is icon}}</ref>
==Project== [[File:Uppspretta sewing coffee bags.jpg|thumb|The sewing of coffee bags]] The transformation of the tower into an artwork was actuated by an earlier work of the [[Toyism|Toyists]], namely ''De Stip'' (''The Dot'') in [[Emmen, Netherlands|Emmen]], [[Netherlands]], when a [[Gas holder|gas storage container]] of 22 meters high was repainted into a work of art. This Icelandic project was financed partially by the municipality of [[Reykjanesbær]], through sponsorship and [[crowdfunding]].<ref name="Beek 53-55">Beek, W. van der (2014), ''Uppspretta'', pp. 53-55, {{ISBN|978-90-809703-0-4}} {{nl}}</ref> Because of this project, the Toyists were also asked by a hotel in Keflavík, to paint its facade and a dining room in the same style.<ref name="Beek 98-99, 116">Beek, W. van der (2014), ''Uppspretta'', pp. 98–99, 116, {{ISBN|978-90-809703-0-4}} {{nl}}</ref>
The project started on 24 July 2013, and was completed after seven weeks. Eleven Toyists from five different countries were involved.<ref name="Beek 98-99, 116" /> During the activities, Iceland had its worst weather conditions since the summer of 1923. Plastic could not be used as a protection material, because it is impermeable to air. The strong winds blew apart the plastic, revealing the artwork before the project was finished. For that reason, coffee bags were used in order to be able to complete the project. Two hundred of them were sewn together and wrapped around the tower.<ref name="Beek 53-55" />
== Theme and design== Whilst [[toyism]] is to be classified under [[figurative art]], one cannot subdivide it further into one particular style. A common denominator of the artworks of the Toyists is that they seem recognizable as well as unworldly.<ref name="DKB">Drenthe Kunst Breed, [http://drenthekunstbreed.nl/kunst/galerie.asp?G=0&id=52&meer=1 Dejo - Toyisme Studio] {{nl}}</ref> The theme of this artwork is a story that resembles a legend. It was invented by the art group for this occasion.<ref name="Beek 5-14">Beek, W. van der (2014) ''Uppspretta'', pp. 5–14, {{ISBN|978-90-809703-0-4}} {{nl}}</ref> In comparison, other works of this group are based on anecdotes, fantasies and philosophies too.<ref name="DKB" />
{{multiple image|caption_align=right|header_align=center | direction = vertical | header = Sólfar | width = 180 | image1 = | caption1 = [[Jón Gunnar Árnason|Árnason's]] work [[The Sun Voyager|Sólfar]] | alt1 = [[Jón Gunnar Árnason|Árnason's]] work [[The Sun Voyager|Sólfar]] | image2 = Uppspretta Onthulling.jpg | caption2 = the dream boat Sólfar | alt2 = The dream boat Sólfar }}
Sólfar (English: ''[[The Sun Voyager]]'') is a work of the Icelandic artist [[Jón Gunnar Árnason]] and was the inspiration for the dream boat that brought Uppspretta back to Iceland. Árnason intended his creation to be a ''dream boat'' which travels to undiscovered areas.<ref>Wide Sea | No Anchor, [http://wideseanoanchor.com/iceland-land-of-puffins/ Sun Voyager], and Travel Bunny, [https://web.archive.org/web/20150910201019/http://thetravelbunny.com/2015/09/10/reykjavik-design-iceland/ Reykjavik – Iceland’s Design Destination]</ref> There's a dream boat in the story of the toyists as well, that brings the main character Uppspretta back to Iceland IJsland. In the images at the right the inspiration of the ''Sólfar'' of Árnason can be observed in the painting of the toyists.<ref name="Beek 5-14" />
Another inspiration came from Iceland, like a [[geyser]]; Uppspretta means ''source''. The [[viking]]s, who are believed by the artists to be the first inhabitants of Iceland, appear in the form of [[Freyja]], the goddess of love from the [[Norse mythology]]. There's also an image of a [[Viking ships|viking ship]].<ref>Beek, W. van der (2014), ''Uppspretta'', pp. 36–44, {{ISBN|978-90-809703-0-4}} {{nl}}</ref>
== The story behind == The main character of this story is a [[puffin]] named Uppspretta, a curious bird that wanted to discover the world. On his search, he read many books on the history of [[Iceland]]. When he discovered that its first citizens came from [[Norway]], he decided to go and find his female puffin there. His parents had warned him that he was not capable of flying above land, but he ignored their warning, flew over land, and fell to earth.<ref name="Beek 5-14" />
However, he did not land in Norway, but to the south in the [[Netherlands]]. There he was found by a man that took care of him. At the man’s home Uppspretta fell asleep and dreamed about people and music. In his dreams a ship came into sight that took him aboard, travelled over the seas, and subsequently through the air to Keflavík. When he arrived at home, he married a female puffin from Norway and became the leader of all puffins on Iceland.<ref name="Beek 5-14" />
[[File:The Legend of Uppspretta.jpg|left|thumb|500px|<center>representation of the travel of Uppspretta</center>]] {{clear}}
== Gallery == <gallery> Uppspretta in Keflavik.jpg|Landscape of Keflavík Uppspretta in winter.jpg|Uppspretta in winter TOYISTEN BIJ UPPSPRETTA.jpg|Toyists at Uppspretta Toyism Mural Hotel Keflavik cropped.jpg|Facade of the local hotel </gallery>
== External links == * [http://www.uppspretta.com/ Official website]
==References== {{Commons category}} {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: v2.0 - Repaired 1 link to disambiguation page - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[Aloha (film)]]
revision.text:
{{cleanup|reason=edit to remove less of a specific stance in lead, edit for flow|date=June 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=January 2017}}'''Whitewashing''' in beauty is a phenomenon in the intersection of the [[fashion industry]], [[digital photography]], [[mass media]], [[marketing]] and [[advertising]]. It describes a situation in which the skin tone of non-white women (less often of men) – when depicted in magazine covers, advertisements, commercials, music videos, etc. – is, digitally [[retouching|retouched]] or physically modified to appear [[white]]r. Whitewashing can also present itself in the alteration of [[Hair|hair texture]] to resemble [[Eurocentrism|Eurocentric]] beauty ideals of straight hair. Whitewashing can be seen in the form of skin whitening, either digitally or with harmful [[Skin whitening|skin bleaching]] products, or by chemically relaxing textured hair to make it conform to Eurocentric beauty standards. Additionally, [[plastic surgery]] can be used to alter features to make them appear more European, such as [[East Asian blepharoplasty|double eyelid surgery.]]
Whitewashing has been seen for centuries in the [[Whitewashing in media|media]], through film, photography, advertising, etc. Whitewashing in [[Hollywood]] is a prevalent issue, often attributed to the lack of racial diversity in the industry itself. Advertising companies often will airbrush their models to make them appear to have lighter skin, as seen in the [[L'Oréal|L'oreal]]<nowiki/>campaign with [[Beyoncé]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/aug/08/advertising.usa|title=L'Oreal accused of 'whitening' Beyoncé Knowles in cosmetics ad|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=2008-08-08|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref>
Whitewashing can also be seen when a film or television show based on a book or other precedent decides to rewrite a non-white role as white and use a white actor to portray the role. This is not to be confused with [[blackface]], which is when a person who is not Black attempts to portray a darker skin tone with makeup or digital editing. This type of whitewashing is most common in the film industry and has been a problem since the beginning of Hollywood.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/hollywood-has-whitewashed-asian-stories-decades-year-they-couldn-t-n830241|title=Hollywood has whitewashed Asian stories for decades. This year, they couldn't ignore the backlash.|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en-US}}</ref> More people of color are being represented in the industry as of late, but whitewashing remains a prevalent issue that can affect self-image of young children whose races have been marginalized in film.'
Cultural whitewashing is also common in the media, in which a culture's traditions are tweaked to satisfy Western stereotypes, such as in the popular film [[Step Up (franchise)|Step Up]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vagabomb.com/Cultural-Appropriation-Whitewashing-Everything-I-Loved-about-Step-up-Suddenly-Seemed-Wrong/|title=Cultural Appropriation & Whitewashing: Everything I Loved about Step up Suddenly Seemed Wrong|last=VagaBomb|date=2017-09-07|work=VagaBomb|access-date=2018-03-30|language=En}}</ref>
== Popular examples ==
=== Advertising === A clear example of beauty whitewashing is a [[L'Oreal]] advertising campaign featuring [[Beyoncé Knowles]] in which her skin was digitally retouched to appear lighter. This brought the corporation under fire for a significant period. Other examples include celebrities [[Halle Berry]], [[Brandy Norwood|Brandy]], [[Mariah Carey]], [[Rihanna]], [[Freida Pinto]], [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Tyra Banks]], [[Leona Lewis]], [[Jennifer Hudson]], [[Gabourey Sidibe]] and [[Queen Latifah]], in which these figures were subjected to skin lightening during the editing stage of promotional photoshoots.
The photo and video-sharing app, [[Snapchat]], also attracted public criticism in 2016 for potential whitewashing in its photo filters.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/snapchat-filters-flower-crown-beautifying-skin-whiter-lightening-controversy-a7036261.html|title=Snapchat criticised over 'filters' which appear to 'whitewash' users' skin|date=18 May 2016|work=The Independent|publisher=}}</ref> A particular target of this outcry was the use of words such as "beautify" and "pretty" associated with the skin-lightening filters.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/photography/snapchat-white-wash/|title=Snapchat accused of whitewashing its users through ‘beautify’ filter|last=Chang|first=Lulu|date=18 May 2016|work=DigitalTrends}}</ref>
=== Film === Recently, [[Rupert Sanders]]’ Hollywood rendition of the 1995 Japanese manga film ''[[Ghost in the Shell (2017 film)|Ghost In the Shell]]'' came under scrutiny for casting a white actress ([[Scarlett Johansson]],) to play the Japanese protagonist.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/03/31/here-s-how-ghost-in-the-shell-tries-and-fails-to-atone-for-its-whitewashing|title=Here’s How ‘Ghost in the Shell’ Tries (and Fails) to Atone for Its Whitewashing|last=Leon|first=Melissa|date=2017-03-31|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-03-02|language=en}}</ref> Though this wasn't physical whitewashing through skin whitening or hair relaxant, it is still considered whitewashing since a white actress was used instead of a Japanese one and the role was rewritten for a white actress.
In the 2014 film [[Aloha (2015 film)|''Aloha'']], directed by [[Cameron Crowe]], [[Emma Stone]] (a white actress) was cast for the role of Captain Allison Ng, a woman who was partially Hawaiian. Similar to ''[[Ghost in the Shell (2017 film)|Ghost In the Shell]],'' a white actress was used in place of a person of color, effectively whitewashing the role and the film itself.
=== Public Figures === Typically, women primarily use products to lighten their skin, but in many cases men also do.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hunter|first1=Margaret|title=Buying Racial Capital: Skin-Bleaching and Cosmetic Surgery in a Globalized World|url=https://www.mills.edu/academics/faculty/soc/mhunter/Hunter_Buying%20Racial%20Capital.pdf|website=The Journal of Pan African Studies|publisher= |volume=4|issue=4|year=2011|page=143|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> Former professional baseball star, [[Sammy Sosa]] admitted to using skin bleaching cream in an interview with "[[Primer Impacto]]" of the Univision Spanish network.<ref name="Sosa: Cream has bleached skin">{{cite web|last1=Rojas|first1=Enrique|title=Sosa: Cream has bleached skin|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/news/story?id=4642952|website=ESPN|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> Sammy Sosa said, "It's a bleaching cream that I apply before going to bed and whitens my skin some… It's a cream that I have, that I use to soften [my skin], but has bleached me some. I'm not racist, I live my life happily." <ref name="Sosa: Cream has bleached skin" />
== Critique == The reasons for altering [[Human skin color|skin tone]] in advertisements are believed to be primarily marketing purposes, more specifically directly appealing to whiter ethnicities, which are generally the strongest [[target group]]s in consumer-driven areas such as [[Europe]] and [[United States|America]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mire|first=Amina|year=2001|title=Skin-Bleaching: Poison, Beauty, Power and the Politics of the Colour Line|url=http://search.proquest.com/genderwatch/docview/194908202/C3A77B0AF8444C03PQ/5?accountid=7418|journal=Resources for Feminist Research|volume=28.3|pages=13–38|via=ProQuest}}</ref> Skin tone manipulation can also reflect the implicit [[Physical attractiveness|beauty standards]] or ideals that the marketers perpetuate.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Watson|first=Stevie|last2=DeJong|first2=Penelope|year=2011|title=Ethical Responses To Public Allegations Of Skin Tone Manipulation In Print Advertising: Consumer Indifference Or Consumer Concern?|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/detail/detail?sid=00f70588-2f88-44db-8e39-c64075eb7445%40sessionmgr120&vid=0&hid=112&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWRzLWxpdmUmc2NvcGU9c2l0ZQ%3d%3d#db=ufh&AN=67526247|journal=Journal of Promotion Management|volume=17.4|pages=396–406|via=Communication & Mass Media Complete|doi=10.1080/10496491.2011.620485}}</ref> Beauty whitewash is criticized for distorting general perceptions of reality, exuding a twisted sense of beauty, and having a negative influence on women, children, and communities alike.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=Ashley|year=2015|title=Picture [Im]Perfect: Photoshop Redefining Beauty In Cosmetic Advertisements, Giving False Advertising A Run For The Money|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/detail/detail?sid=f9fa4ec1-adeb-4419-8ea1-e19555aa3581%40sessionmgr103&vid=0&hid=112&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWRzLWxpdmUmc2NvcGU9c2l0ZQ%3d%3d#AN=108802574&db=a9h|journal=Texas Review Of Entertainment & Sports Law|volume=16.2|pages=87–105|via=Academic Search Complete}}</ref>
These [[Eurocentrism|Eurocentric]] ideals are forced upon people of color, creating [[Hierarchy|hierarchies]] within their own communities. Ultimately, whitewashing creates social tension not only between White and non-White communities, but also between groups who resemble the more established beauty standards, such as lighter-skinned African Americans, and the groups who do not, including darker-skinned African Americans.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hunter |first=Margaret |title=The Persistent Problem of Colorism: Skin Tone, Status, and Inequality |url=https://www.mills.edu/academics/faculty/soc/mhunter/The%20Persistent%20Problem%20of%20Colorism.pdf |journal=Sociology Compass |publication-date=2007 |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=237–254 |doi=10.1111/j.1751-9020.2007.00006.x |access-date=2016-12-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170305034927/https://www.mills.edu/academics/faculty/soc/mhunter/The%20Persistent%20Problem%20of%20Colorism.pdf# |archive-date=2017-03-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> This phenomenon can apply to both men and women of color.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Veras |first=Edlin |title=He's Dark, Dark; Colorism Among African American Men |url=http://scholarworks.gsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1035&context=aas_theses |journal=Georgia State University |publication-date=2016}}</ref>
Kai Nelson believes that whitewashing has a negative impact on children in African American communities as well.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Nelson|first=Kai|year=2016|title=Where's the Representation? The Impact of White Washing on Black Children|url=http://scholarsarchive.jwu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1037&context=ac_symposium|journal=Academic Symposium of Undergraduate Scholarship|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The media does not always give an accurate view of the races that they are depicting, resulting in a diminishment of self-confidence in African American children. Nelson explains that children interpret the altering of [[Human skin color|skin color]] in the beauty industry in a negative way, and can develop a viewpoint that they are "unattractive" and "undesirable".<ref name=":0" /> Because of the lack of Black role models in [[Media culture|popular media]], this causes them to see the Caucasian community as the "default [[race (human categorization)|race]]".<ref name=":0" />
As Ronald Hall describes in his ''[[Journal of Black Studies]]'', whitewashing has caused [[people of color]] to develop a "bleaching syndrome" which causes an internalization of preference for the dominant, or White, culture’s ideals. This results in people of color developing a contempt for dark skin because it is regarded as an obstacle for [[Cultural assimilation|assimilation]]. However, despite adopting white cultural values, people of color are still barred from full assimilation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hall|first=Ronald|year=1995|title=The Bleaching Syndrome: African Americans' Response to Cultural Domination Vis-a-Vis Skin Color|url=|journal=Journal of Black Studies|volume=26.2|pages=172–84|doi=10.1177/002193479502600205}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Discrimination based on skin color]] * [[Whitewashing in film]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * Adam Elliott-Cooper, [http://ceasefiremagazine.co.uk/anti-imperialist-9/ "The Whitewash of Black Beauty"], ''Ceasefire, The Anti-Imperialist'', 11 June 2011 * Lindsay Kite, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110306151312/http://www.beautyredefined.net/beauty-whitewashed-how-white-ideals-exclude-women-of-color/ "Beauty Whitewashed: How White Ideals Exclude Women Of Color"], ''beautyredefined.net'', 28 February 2011 {{dead link|date=November 2017}} * [http://www.raceandtechnology.wordpress.com/2014/12/10/whitewashing-in-mass-media-exploring-colorism-and-the-damaging-effects-of-beauty-hierarchies/ "‘Whitewashing’ in Mass Media: Exploring Colorism and the Damaging Effects of Beauty Hierarchies."] ''Race and Technology'', 10 December 2014
[[Category:Beauty]] [[Category:Colorism]] [[Category:Racism]] [[Category:Mass media]] [[Category:Digital photography]] [[Category:Marketing techniques]]
